dc:description: DSE was first reported in relation to musculocontractural Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type 2 (mcEDS2) in 2013 (Muller et al., PMID:23704329). This protein coding gene maps to chromosome 6q22. The protein encoded by this gene is localized to the endoplasmic reticulum where it functions to convert D-glucuronic acid to L-iduronic acid residues during the biosynthesis of dermatan sulfate. To date, 9 specific variants have been reported in relation to 15 cases (Minatogawa et al., PMID:35842784, Yoshizawa et al., PMID:36833362). These mutations represent homozygous missense, frameshift, and nonsense mutations. Common symptoms among the reported cases include characteristic facial features, congenital contractures, joint hypermobility, skin manifestations, and muscle weakness. The gene-disease relationship is also supported by functional evidence including reduced DSE protein expression in patient-derived fibroblasts (Muller et al., PMID:23704329, Syx et al., PMID:25703627, Minatogawa et al., PMID:35842784) and lack of dermatan sulfate in patient urine samples (Latrup et al., PMID:32130795). Further evidence comes from skin composition and strength changes and altered protein expression observed in DSE-/- mice (Maccarana et al., PMID:19687302). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between DSE and mcEDS2. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation GCEP on the meeting date September 4, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: This patient and her older brother were born to consanguineous parents, so we reduced the score slightly.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lautrup Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing was performed and a homozygous frameshift variant was identified in DSE (NM_013352.4, c.996dupT, p.(Val333Cysfs*4))
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
craniofacial characteristics (hypertelorism, blue sclera, midfacial hypoplasia), skeletal features (pectus and spinal deformities, characteristic finger shapes, progressive talipes deformities), skin features
(fine or acrogeria-like palmar creases), and ocular refractive errors

evidence.rdfs:label: Schirwani P2
evidence.detectionMethod:
Focused clinical exome analysis identified a homozygous
missense variant c.1763A > G p.(His588Arg) in the DSE gene, confirmed
by bidirectional sanger sequencing. This novel variant is not
found in population databases and in silico analysis predicts this to
variant to be damaging at highly conserved amino-acid. There is,
however, no functional evidence for the variant and so it is a variant of
uncertain clinical significance according to ACMG criteria (Richards
et al., 2015). Parental studies confirmed that they each had the variant
in heterozygous form.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
At birth he had a generous
sized anterior fontanelle. His ear pinna on the right was flattened.
There was severe bilateral talipes equinovarus, arachnodactyly of fingers
with contractures at the metacarpophalangeal joints, lack of
flexion at interphalangeal joints with absence of distal flexion creases,
adducted thumbs and flexion contractures at the wrists. There were no
obvious eye abnormalities. Cardiac assessment identified a moderate
sized secundum atrial septal defect. Initial cranial ultrasound showed
mild ventriculomegaly but postnatal brain MRI scan was normal.
On review at 13 months of age he was noted to have brachycephaly,
protruding ears and a prominent nasal bridge with depressed nasal tip.
His palpebral fissures were short and downslanting. His palate was
intact and uvula broad but not bifid.
He walked at 21 months and on review at 26 months appeared to
have good developmental progress with single words and some word
joining. He had residual contractures of the 3rd digit and thumbs but
was not particularly hindered in his fine motor abilities. He had bruises
on his legs but no abnormal scarring, subcutaneous haematomas or
fragility noted. There was a mild torticollis.

evidence.dc:description: Limited information on this patient - should this be down-scored?

evidence.rdfs:label: Ranza Patient 18
evidence.detectionMethod: Patient initially had an unknown diagnosis but was found to have this variant thru whole exome sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Bilateral adducted thumbs, long and tapering fingers, bilateral talipes equinovarua, and hip dislocations

evidence.dc:description: We considered down-scoring this variant because the deletion is in the last exon. This exon is very long and the variant results in 58% loss of the protein, so it seems unlikely that it would function. We did down-score due to consanguinity.

evidence.rdfs:label: Schirwani P1
evidence.detectionMethod:
Genomic DNA obtained from the patient was screened for sequence variants. Exome data was assessed for variants of potential significance firstly in a panel of four genes associated with acromesomelic dysplasia syndromes (BMPR1B, GDF5, NPR2, TRPS1). Subsequently, using a broadly phenotype-agnostic approach, the analysis was expanded. to include rare (< 0.1% minor allele frequency in the EXAC dataset) (Karczewski et al., 2017) variants in a list of 2506 genes associated with developmental disorders. Variants were then triaged in a semi-automated process by possible deleterious and functional effects, minor allele frequency, inheritance pattern, zygosity and phenotypic fit (using Human Phenotype Ontology terms). 

A final candidate shortlist (in this case, a single variant) was then assessed clinically for phenotypic consistency, and confirmed using bidirectional Sanger sequencing of the appropriate
genomic region.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
bilateral congenital talipes equinovarus, characteristic facial features,
myopia, hyperextensible skin at the elbows, significant palmar wrinkling, bilateral inguinal hernias and chronic
leg, back and joint pain

evidence.dc:description: Heterologous expression of mutant full-length and soluble recombinant DSE proteins showed a loss of activity towards partially desulfated DS. Patient-derived fibroblasts also showed a significant reduction in epimerase activity.

evidence.rdfs:label: Muller Case 1
evidence.detectionMethod:
Genome-wide homozygosity scan and copy-number variant  were performed
Homozygous DSE missense mutation, c.803C>T (p.S268L) in a patient with MCEDS in DSE was found to represent a highly conserved residue in DSE orthologs and in human DSEL.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Also had prominent ears, congenital contractures of the thumbs and the feet, hypermobility of finger, elbow, and knee joints, normal cognition.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing included sequence analysis of CHST14 which revealed no mutations. High density SNP array genotyping which identified homozygous genomic regions.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ullah Patient V-1
evidence.detectionMethod:
Whole-exome sequencing (WES) analysis of two affected (V-1 andV-2) and unaffected (IV-1) individuals was performed to investigate the causative gene mutation responsible for phenotype in the family. The variant (NM_001080976.1, c.2813T>A, p.Val938Asp) in DSE in both patients is the most probable cause of the phenotype in this family. According to the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) classification, the variant is of uncertain significance because its homozygous allele is absent in public databases (PM2; moderate) and gnomAD missense Z-score is 2.03 compared to synonymous Z-score of 1.08 (PP2; supporting). 

Sanger sequencing (SS) of DSE in all avail-able family members was performed using standard methods for the autosomal recessive segregation of the affected allele in the family. Eight family members including three phenotypically normal parents (IV-1, IV-3, and IV-4) are heterozygous and affected proband (V-1) including his affected siblings (V-2,V-3,V-4, and V-5) are homozygous. The SS chromato-graphs of eight family members are shown in Figure 3. On the basis of the above-mentioned findings, it is concluded that the variant(c.2813T>A, p.Val938Asp) in DSE segregated in the family and is likely to be pathogenic.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Distinctive facial features, long slender fingers, joint laxity, swan neck deformity, long toes, finger webbing, bilateral pes cavus feet

evidence.dc:description: Only 2 affected members of this family.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lautrup Family 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
craniofacial characteristics (hypertelorism, blue sclera, midfacial hypoplasia), skeletal features (pectus and spinal deformities, characteristic finger shapes, progressive talipes deformities), skin features
(fine or acrogeria-like palmar creases), and ocular refractive errors

evidence.dc:description: Only 2 affected members in this family, so will not include.
evidence.rdfs:label: Syx Family 5

member.rdfs:label: Syx P6
member.detectionMethod:
The authors sequenced the DSE gene in P6, and identified
a homozygous c.799A>G transition (c.[799A>G];[799A>G]) in
exon 4, leading to the substitution of a highly conserved arginine
residue by a glycine (p.(Arg267Gly)) in the epimerase domain.
member.phenotypeFreeText:
Frequent, often large hematomas occurring after minor trauma which left
residual calcifications and pigmentations on the skin. 
Long and slender fingers.
Joint and muscle pain, particularly in the hands, which limited daily activities.
Cardiovascular examination revealed mixomatous mitral valve and rupture
of the valvular chordae, necessitating mitral valve replacement. 
Small mouth. 
Wrinkled and saggy eyebags, cheeks and neck.
member.previousTestingDescription:
Molecular analysis of CHST14 failed to identify a causal variant
in P6 and P7. 

We next sequenced the DSE gene in P6, and identified
a homozygous c.799A>G transition (c.[799A>G];[799A>G]) in
exon 4, leading to the substitution of a highly conserved arginine
residue by a glycine (p.(Arg267Gly)) in the epimerase domain. This
missense variant is located immediately adjacent to the amino acid
residue (p.(Ser268Leu)) substituted in the initially described patient
(Fig. 3B and C) [M¨uller et al., 2013]. 

In silico prediction programs
designate this variant as pathogenic (Supp. Table S1).

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Frequent, often large hematomas occurring after minor trauma which left
residual calcifications and pigmentations on the skin. 
Long and slender fingers.
Joint and muscle pain, particularly in the hands, which limited daily activities.
Cardiovascular examination revealed mixomatous mitral valve and rupture
of the valvular chordae, necessitating mitral valve replacement. 
Small mouth. 
Wrinkled and saggy eyebags, cheeks and neck.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ullah Family 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Distinctive facial features, long slender fingers, joint laxity, swan neck deformity, long toes, finger webbing, bilateral pes cavus feet

evidence.dc:description:
Fibroblast cultures of the two siblings with the DSE variants (P6 and P7)
were available for further analysis. Although the mutant DSE mRNA transcripts were stable in
dermal fibroblasts of P6 and P7 harboring a homozygous DSE
p.(Arg267Gly) missense variant (Fig. 4B), Western blot analysis
showed a severe reduction of the mutant DS-epi1 protein produced
by fibroblasts of P6 and P7, suggesting degradation of the mutant
protein (Fig. 4C).
The patient was born to consanguineous parents, so we reduced the score.
No dermatan sulfate was detected in the urine sample from patient 1, suggesting a complete depletion of DS.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lautrup Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of CHST14 and DSE was performed for patient 1 based on clinical suspicion of mcEDS. No pathogenic variants were detected in CHST14; a homozygous nonsense variant was identified in DSE (NM_013352.4, c.960T>A, p.(Tyr320*)) (Figure 2a).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
large anterior
fontanel, brachycephaly, low hairline, wide neck, hypertelorism,
blue sclera, short nose with hypoplastic columella,
long philtrum, and thin upper lip vermilion. He had bilateral
adducted thumbs, arachnodactyly, and rocker bottom feet, but
did not exhibit talipes equinovarus. He had umbilical hernia,
diastasis recti, bilateral hydronephrosis, and cryptorchidism.
He experienced recurrent constipation, which was treated
with laxatives. Echocardiography revealed an atrial septal defect
and patent ductus arteriosus. He exhibited delayed motor
development and mild hypotonia, strabismus and cryptorchidism, myopia, sensorineural hearing loss, shoulder luxation and large
subcutaneous hematomas at various locations, mild scoliosis
and joint hypermobility, and underwent surgery for pes
cavus at 11 years of age. His skin was hyperextensible with
delayed wound healing. At 15 years of age, he had a self-limiting
hemoptysis with no evidence of tuberculosis. He had downslanting palpebral fissures, grey sclera,
but no hypertelorism. His ears were not rotated or low-set;
however, his right ear showed underfolded helix, lower insertion
of the lobule than on the left side, and pits on the
posterior conchae. He had dental crowding, and his skin
was hyperextensible, with fine palmar (Figure 1b) and
solar creases, and broadened surgical scars on the right
foot (Figure 1d). His fingers were long and slender with
joint laxity and a swan-neck deformity, as well as the radial
deviation of the bilateral second to fourth fingers (Figure
1a). He had bilateral pes cavus (Figure 1e), mild pectus
excavatum (Figure 1c), and lumbar scoliosis. He had no
echocardiographic abnormalities,

evidence.dc:description: Reduced the score slightly due to consanguinity. There is good functional evidence.

DS moieties were markedly reduced, but remained present, in the conditioned medium and cell fraction from cultured fibroblasts of the patient, and were not detected in urine from the patient, compared with the findings in the control subject (Supporting Information: Table S1, Figure S1). The DSE activities in cultured skin fibroblasts from the patient and the control subject as well as in COS-7 cells transfected with p.Tyr867*-mutant or wild-type DSE were evaluated by measuring the total amount of glucuronic acid (GlcUA) converted from iduronic acid (IdoUA) in DS. The DSE activities were significantly reduced in the fibroblasts of the patient, compared with those of the control subject (Figure 2a, Supporting Information: Figure S2a–c), and were also reduced in the COS-7 cells transfected with p.Tyr867*-mutant DSE compared with those transfected with wild-type DSE (Figure 2b, Supporting Information: Figure S2d–f).

evidence.rdfs:label: Minatogawa Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod:
Genomic DNA was extracted from the peripheral blood lymphocytes. A next-generation sequencing-based custom panel analysis including 52 genes for heritable connective tissue disorders was performed 

A novel nonsense variant in exon 6 of DSE (NM_013352.4:c.2601C>A:p.(Tyr867*)) was identified homozygously. The variant was confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The patient developed recurrent large subcutaneous hematomas.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: extensive molecular, glycobiological, and pathological study using specimens from the patient. Peripheral blood samples, urine samples, and skin specimens from his left upper arm were collected

evidence.dc:description: DSE mouse models exhibit similar phenotypes to patients with mcEDS, such as suppressed growth and skin fragility and deformation of the collagen fibrils.
evidence.rdfs:label: DSE Mouse Model
